channel.title: NYT > Top Stories
channel.copyright: Copyright 2026 The New York Times Company

item.title: Read the Texts Between Trump and Norway’s Prime Minister
item.description: In the exchange on Sunday, Norway’s leader sought to “de-escalate” the growing conflict over Greenland and Mr. Trump’s latest tariff threat.
item.dc:creator: Jeffrey Gettleman
item.media:credit: Hannah McKay/Reuters
item.media:description: President Trump texted Jonas Gahr Store, Norway’s leader, blaming his country for not awarding Mr. Trump the Nobel Peace Prize.

item.title: Trump Has an Offramp on Greenland. He Doesn’t Seem to Want It.
item.description: The strategic importance of Greenland is growing, and NATO has underinvested in Arctic security. But President Trump, intent on ownership, is rebuffing deals with Europe to solve the problem.
item.dc:creator: David E. Sanger
item.media:credit: Allison Robbert for The New York Times
item.media:description: For President Trump, the sheer size of Greenland’s territory holds part of the appeal; it is about three times the size of Texas, and bigger than Alaska.

item.title: Federal Reserve Inquiry Clouds Trump’s Supreme Court Bid to Oust Lisa Cook
item.description: The court is set to hear Ms. Cook’s case challenging her firing as the Justice Department investigates Jerome H. Powell, the central bank chair.
item.dc:creator: Ann E. Marimow

item.title: Trump’s Trade Negotiator Says Response to Court Loss Would Be Immediate
item.description: If the Supreme Court rules against its tariffs, the Trump administration would begin replacing them immediately, said Jamieson Greer, the United States Trade Representative.
item.dc:creator: Ana Swanson
item.media:credit: Haiyun Jiang/The New York Times
item.media:description: Jamieson Greer, the United States Trade Representative, on Air Force One in October.

item.title: Valentino Garavani, Regal Designer and Fashion’s ‘Last Emperor,’ Dies at 93
item.description: Valentino, as he was called, created one of the most durable and fashionable labels and became an equal of his high society customers.
item.dc:creator: Vanessa Friedman
item.media:credit: Warrick Page for The International Herald Tribune
item.media:description: Valentino Garavani in 2012. He created and sold an image of high glamour that helped define Italian style for generations. “I always look for beauty, beauty,” he said.

item.title: La Dolce Vita, the Valentino Way
item.description: Archival photographs, fashion layouts and anecdotes from celebrity clients: A new book is devoted to all things Valentino.
item.dc:creator: Marisa Meltzer

item.title: Survivors of Deadly Train Crash in Spain Describe Hellish Scenes
item.description: Photographs show a tangled mess of metal, wires and broken glass at the scene of the crash, which killed at least 39 people.
item.dc:creator: Jason Horowitz, Samuel Granados and José Bautista
item.media:credit: Susana Vera/Reuters
item.media:description: Members of the Spanish Civil Guard, along with other emergency personnel, work next to one of the trains involved in the accident near Adamuz, Spain, on Monday.

item.title: What We Know About the Deadly High-Speed Train Crash in Spain
item.description: Sunday’s train crash in the southern region of Andalucía was the deadliest in Spain since at least 2013, killing at least 40 people.
item.dc:creator: Max Kim
item.media:credit: Alex Gallegos/Reuters
item.media:description: A person affected by a deadly train derailment is transferred for treatment to the Caseta Municipal in Adamuz, Spain, on Sunday.

item.title: Want to Eat Healthier? Listen to Your Hunger.
item.description: In the third part of a monthlong series, Pete Wells and experts say a healthier diet begins with understanding what drives your eating, and slowing down.
item.dc:creator: Pete Wells
item.media:credit: Julia Gartland for The New York Times. Food Stylist: Barrett Washburne.

item.title: Splits Emerge Among Venezuelans as Revolutionary Dream Fades
item.description: Supporters of former president Hugo Chávez, the anti-American socialist, are struggling to come to terms with their government’s pact with Washington.
item.dc:creator: Maria Abi-Habib
item.media:credit: The New York Times
item.media:description: Demonstrators demanding the release of President Nicolás Maduro in Caracas, Venezuela, on Friday.

item.title: What to Know About Hezbollah’s Ties to Venezuela
item.description: U.S. authorities have accused Hezbollah of complicity in drug trafficking and money laundering schemes in Venezuela.
item.dc:creator: Christina Goldbaum
item.media:credit: Sergey Ponomarev for The New York Times
item.media:description: Hezbollah fighters at the Lebanon-Syria border in 2017.

item.title: Inside Minnesota Hospitals, ICE Agents Unnerve Staff
item.description: As federal agents swarm the Twin Cities, their presence has also grown in medical centers. Health care workers are pushing back.
item.dc:creator: Jazmine Ulloa
item.media:credit: Jamie Kelter Davis for The New York Times
item.media:description: Hennepin Healthcare in Minneapolis on Sunday.

item.title: Before Urban Raids, Border Patrol Tested Tactics in California Farm Country
item.description: Just before President Trump took office, Border Patrol agents led by Gregory Bovino arrested immigrants in Kern County using the same playbook later seen in places like Chicago and Minneapolis. Then a federal judge ordered them to stop.
item.dc:creator: Orlando Mayorquín, Jesus Jiménez and Mark Abramson

item.title: Prominent Catholic Clerics Denounce U.S. Foreign Policy
item.description: Citing recent events in Venezuela, Ukraine and Greenland, three cardinals said their statement was inspired by Pope Leo.
item.dc:creator: Ruth Graham
item.media:credit: Gianni Cipriano for The New York Times
item.media:description: Cardinal Blase Cupich said in an interview that, among his fellow cardinals, there was “a sense of alarm about the way things were going in the world.”

item.title: No Country Has Ever Been Held Responsible for Genocide. Can This Lawyer Change That?
item.description: Philippe Sands, one of the world’s pre-eminent human rights attorneys, is arguing the case against Myanmar at The Hague.
item.dc:creator: Michael Steinberger
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
38 Londres Street: On Impunity, Pinochet in England, and a Nazi in Patagonia (Book)
item.media:credit: Nadav Kander for The New York Times

item.title: A Look Through a Century of Times Reporting From Antarctica
item.description: Generations of Times journalists have journeyed there with scientists. Their coverage traces humankind’s changing relationship with the most mysterious continent.
item.dc:creator: Raymond Zhong
item.media:credit: The New York Times, St. Louis Post-Dispatch
item.media:description: One of the dog teams of the Byrd Expedition resting in the foothills near the Axel Heiberg Glacier on the Ross Ice Shelf in Antarctica in 1930.

item.title: Elon Musk Spends $10 Million to Help Nate Morris in Kentucky Senate Race
item.description: Elon Musk, the world’s richest person, backed Nate Morris, a Republican businessman, in the primary race to succeed Senator Mitch McConnell in Kentucky.
item.dc:creator: Theodore Schleifer
item.media:credit: Haiyun Jiang/The New York Times
item.media:description: Elon Musk at the Kennedy Center in November. After his falling out with President Trump last year, he has inched back toward the Republican fold.

item.title: In a State Notorious for Scandal, Corruption Fighters Are Targeted
item.description: An anonymous negative ad campaign has been aimed at New Jersey’s departing attorney general. “It’s a warning to others,” one political scientist said.
item.dc:creator: Tracey Tully
item.media:credit: Hannah Beier for The New York Times
item.media:description: Attorney General Matthew J. Platkin of New Jersey is leaving office but nonetheless is being targeted by campaign-style mailers.

item.title: China’s Birthrate Plunges to Lowest Level Since 1949
item.description: China’s population fell for a fourth straight year and its birthrate tumbled as policymakers failed to slow a demographic crisis.
item.dc:creator: Alexandra Stevenson
item.media:credit: Wu Hao/EPA, via Shutterstock
item.media:description: Despite sweeping efforts to boost births, China’s population has shrunk and aged for a fourth straight year as deaths again outnumbered births.

item.title: Real Estate Crash Weighs on China’s Economic Growth
item.description: Falling apartment prices have erased the savings of millions of Chinese households, but exports lifted the economy to 5 percent growth last year.
item.dc:creator: Keith Bradsher
item.media:credit: Qilai Shen for The New York Times
item.media:description: China is still grappling with a property market crash that began four years ago, after many years of overbuilding.

item.title: Could Mamdani’s Child Care Plan Encourage a Baby Boomlet in New York?
item.description: Some New Yorkers hope that raising a child in the city could become more affordable thanks to Mayor Zohran Mamdani’s plans for free child care and preschool.
item.dc:creator: Emma G. Fitzsimmons
item.media:credit: Eva Woolridge for The New York Times
item.media:description: Mallorie Ekström and her husband, Andy Orge, worried about the cost of having a sibling for their daughter, Valentina. Mayor Zohran Mamdani’s plan for free child care has them feeling more optimistic.

item.title: ‘Masquerade’ Reimagined ‘Phantom,’ and the Fans Are Flocking
item.description: An immersive adaptation of Andrew Lloyd Webber’s musical has seen some people return a dozen times since it began performances last summer.
item.dc:creator: Sarah Bahr
item.media:credit: George Etheredge for The New York Times

item.title: The Popularity of ‘Heated Rivalry’ Masks a Darker Trend of Anti-Gay Bias
item.description: We seem to be in a new era of anti-gay prejudice.
item.dc:creator: Tessa E.S. Charlesworth and Eli J. Finkel
item.media:credit: Illustration by Sam Whitney/The New York Times

item.title: There’s a reason Trump Is Targeting Minneapolis
item.description: Minneapolis stands in defiance to Trump’s dark vision of America.
item.dc:creator: Lydia Polgreen
item.media:credit: Mark Peterson for The New York Times

item.title: Has the U.S. Lost Measles Elimination Status?
item.description: It’s unclear whether the United States can keep its designation as a country that officially eliminated the disease.
item.dc:creator: Teddy Rosenbluth and Apoorva Mandavilli

item.title: At the Center of Trump’s Vision for Rebuilding Ukraine: BlackRock
item.description: The world’s largest asset manager has been enlisted to help build Ukraine’s recovery plan. Some fear it is part of a Trump administration effort to steer the effort toward American business interests.
item.dc:creator: Constant Méheut
item.media:credit: Tyler Hicks/The New York Times
item.media:description: Mezhova, in eastern Ukraine, in December. Ukrainian officials have likened their country’s recovery blueprint to the Marshall Plan, the U.S.-funded project to rebuild Europe after World War II.

item.title: The Rise of Prediction Markets
item.description: Billions of dollars are trading hands on sites like Polymarket and Kalshi, where people bet on everything from Taylor Swift’s wedding date to election outcomes.
item.dc:creator: David Yaffe-Bellany
item.media:credit: Mojo Wang

item.title: Prominent Architecture Firm Is Accused of Illegally Ousting Employees
item.description: A federal labor regulator says the firm, Snohetta, laid off eight employees in retaliation for trying to unionize.
item.dc:creator: Noam Scheiber
item.media:credit: Karsten Moran for The New York Times
item.media:description: Snohetta designed interior spaces at the Summit One Vanderbilt observation complex in Manhattan.
